Since Nature cries "Man should not live alone</br>Or in the cot — or on th' imperial throne;"</br>Since solitude is shunn'd by all, save those</br>Who seek retirement to indulge their woes,</br>Or hide their crimes, or sacrifice to pride,</br>And sigh for follies they no more can guide,</br>Is it not strange the SKILL TO TALK should find</br>So few competitors amongst mankind</br>This master-key of every social charm,</br>Which opes the stores, whence wit and learning arm,</br>Should so neglected rust — be so unknown,</br>That few will grasp what most may call their own.

In every other art we wish to chin</br>The proud distinction of superior fame.</br>In all professions, zealously we strive</br>To keep respect and well-earned praise alive;</br>Yet these must wait occasions to produce</br>Their several claims to ornament, or use.</br>His muse not always can the bard enjoy,</br>—For where's the mistress who is never coy?—</br>The lawyer, prompted by his fame and fees,</br>Can only shine by regular degrees;</br>Nor can the painter always show his skill,</br>Nor yet the scholar wield the scholar's quill;</br>Ev'n he who soothes us by sweet music's strains,</br>And wakes, by turns, the lover's joys and pains,</br>Must, sometimes, sacrifice to forms and hours,</br>And claim assistance from confederate powers.</br>Whilst CONVERSATION, happily design'd,</br>The ready messenger from mind to mind,</br>Acts at all times — and by its charms can raise</br>The instant tribute of distinguish'd praise.

Behold the man!  by genius form'd to sound</br>The finest notes in Conversation's round!</br>What heart-felt praise awaits where'er he goes!</br>How quickly vanish all inferior woes!</br>Mark but his entrance to the social board!</br>A joy springs up, as if by joint accord,</br>Each eye gives welcome as he takes his seat,</br>Each mind anticipates the classic treat,</br>Whene'er he speaks, how hush'd is every tongue,</br>The young grow wiser, and the old grow young,</br>Ev'n folly sits subdued, and would explore</br>Pleasure, or profit from so rich a store.

Say some such master spirit of that court,</br>Where Conversation makes its best report!</br>Where the best evidence for truth is sought,</br>And no appeals from folly's court are brought,</br>What institutes can teach this varying art</br>And give prescriptive rules for every part?</br>To tell what subjects should precisely fit</br>The several groups of gravity, or wit,</br>Would be as endless as to count the train</br>Who fluttering crowd round Fashion's magic fane;</br>Would be as arduous, as with truth to find</br>The several dispositions of mankind.</br>Perhaps to trace the errors of discourse,</br>Explore their bearings — properties and source,</br>How now inelegant they wound the ear,</br>And now with folly dash the mental cheer;</br>Such comments best — may marshal out the way,</br>Thus what to shun will teach us what — to say.

Ere Conversation takes a general line,</br>And various minds in social freedom join,</br>EXPLORE WITH CARE THE SEVERAL RANKS AND NAMES</br>OF ALL AROUND — PROFESSIONS — TASTES — AND CLAIMS,</br>Possess'd of these we gain the readier cue,</br>To pay respect where'er respect is due,</br>Impress'd with these — our feelings turn aside</br>From all that wounds, misfortune — faults — or pride.</br>Who would on green-ey'd jealousy declaim</br>Before the husband injured in his fame?</br>Who would recount the pangs which spendthrifts feel</br>Near him who lavish'd with imprudent zeal?</br>Or fortune claim? — or vaunt of courtly grace,</br>To him who lost his law-suit, or his place?</br>Who talk thus idly — tho' they aim no blow,</br>Nor urge by wanton cruelty, a foe,</br>Nor rage — nor malice stimulate their breast,</br>The deed's chance-medley mischief at the best.

If ignorance of persons — ranks — and names,</br>Can thus produce such inharmonious games,</br>How must he violate the social plan,</br>Who, forms unheeding, plays the ABSENT MAN?</br>Of him who yields to this oblivious pow'r,</br>What strange incongruous follies mark each hour?</br>Dup'd by his tongue — he counter-acts his heart,</br>And thoughtless of the mischief hurls the dart.</br>To the staid maid, whose hopes yet intervene,</br>The age for marriage he proclaims eighteen,</br>Cries "'tis the very point of bloom and prime,</br>And all are tabbies who surpass this time."</br>The insolence of health and youth he'll claim</br>Before the pale, debilitated frame;</br>To her that's homely, rave on charms of face,</br>To him who halts, on dignity and grace,</br>The pow'rs of love recount before the old,</br>And urge the praise of silence to the scold.</br>Once plung'd, in short, no end to error's found,</br>From mere forgetfulness of looking round.</br>Be present then, where'er your part's assign'd,</br>With equals mixed — or with superiors join'd;</br>This recollection gives to all their place,</br>And guards from such ridiculous disgrace.

Though these are failings which our thoughts betray,</br>And lead the mind unknowingly astray,</br>Another yet of ranker growth is nigh,</br>More dang'rous far, and asks a steadier eye,</br>PASSION YCLEP'D — rude — ignorant — and vain,</br>Whose turgid note outswells the level strain,</br>And like the guardless — intermeddling friend,</br>Betrays the cause it rashly would defend.</br>Avaunt infuriate!  with thy sightless rage,</br>Which spares nor self, nor sex, nor friends, nor age,</br>Avaunt!  and let discretion gently teach</br>The milder attributes of grace and speech;</br>Our thoughts thro' these, a grateful welcome find,</br>And shew the polish of a well-bred mind.

Tread not on GOSSIP GROUND, and its domain,</br>Where busy Scandal ever loves to reign,</br>And CURIOSITY, with eager ear,</br>Now hushing ev'ry other sense to hear,</br>Or circulating envious tales and lies,</br>As spleen — caprice — or prejudice supplies.</br>Be ours to leave this babbling talk behind,</br>Which wounds the absent, and depraves the mind,</br>Dissolves the links which kindred hearts should join,</br>And pays the utt'rer back his own base coin.</br>Let us, since life confirms this common fact,</br>"That man with man thro' every stage must act;"</br>To topics turn — our general wants the same—</br>Which best advance and dignify man's fame.</br>What books instruct him — or what arts improve,</br>How virtue charms! — How amiable is love!</br>What laws best govern, or what modes impart</br>The readiest comforts to the suff'ring heart.</br>Such were the themes which ancient poets sung</br>Which blazon'd truth, and silenc'd folly's tongue;</br>Such are the themes whence real joys are found,</br>And throw an harmony on all around.

Sluggish in mind, some ne'er will be prevail'd</br>To join in talk, like midnight ghosts, till hail'd;</br>The answer made — again like ghosts they sit,</br>Unmov'd by humour, argument, or wit;</br>In solemn silence, or in thoughtless stare,</br>The mere associates of an elbow chair.

Others, like actors, catch the cue with art,</br>To tell some story, like their neighbour's, smart—</br>No matter what, so it reflects the other,</br>And claims resemblance to its gossip brother.</br>Thus pair'd for contest — see the Sparlings play!</br>—Regardless what the audience think, or say—</br>Tale after tale they press with ceaseless thirst,</br>"Till Dunce the second, yields to Dunce the first.

Others there are who with the sage inclin'd,</br>Think art is long — hence every thing's defin'd</br>At tedious length — no matter what's the case,</br>Morals — or trifles — politics — or grace.</br>Should lovely woman as a theme arise,</br>They'll first declaim on forehead — lips and eyes;</br>Then to her bosom, like an insect steal,</br>And soil those beauties which they cannot feel;</br>Next to her waist, and then perhaps so low,</br>As sometimes to expatiate on her toe,</br>"That taper'd toe which mocks the lily's white,</br>And shews a nail inexplicably bright,</br>Rear'd by a heel of that proportion'd size,</br>As far excels the Medicean prize."</br>All this is told in such a wire-drawn phrase,</br>So far remov'd from amatory praise,</br>The picture's left unfinish'd and unknown,</br>Whilst "God's last — best reserve" is turn'd to stone.
Thus oft Grimalkin with her mouse will play,</br>Now seize in sport — now seem to turn away,</br>Till quite exhausted from the worrying hour,</br>The little victim 'scopes his tyrant's power.

Howe'er the subject turns — regard this rule,</br>"ASSUME NO LEAD IN CONVERSATION'S SCHOOL;"</br>Nor arm'd with logic-petulance, engage</br>ON ARGUMENT'S HIGH STILTED DANG'ROUS STAGE;</br>From first rate talents Argument will rise</br>With pow'rs, no doubt, to claim the highest prize,</br>Arrest the list'ning ear with magic skill,</br>And turn and wind the passions to its will;</br>Such as when BURKE and JOHNSON shew'd their might</br>In all the grandeur of polemic fight,</br>Their minds gigantic — their contention strong,</br>Their object fame — the fame of ancient song,</br>Whilst burnish'd arms, emitting classic rays,</br>Illum'd the judgment, and commanded praise:</br>When two such heroes in the lists appear,</br>Who had three ears, at such a time should hear.

Again, when ARGUMENT, dispos'd to play,</br>Turns with commanding grace from grave to gay,</br>Its sprightly humour — fanciful, yet true,</br>Arrays the subject in its happiest hue.</br>But sprung from Pride, and nurs'd by Learning's spleen,</br>—Aspiring only to be heard and seen—</br>When as the bully of the mind 'tis found</br>Thund'ring its dogmas with imperious sound,</br>We turn aside, with indignation stung,</br>And loathe this rude monopoly of tongue.</br>All met to please — consign this wordy war,</br>To wrangling Sophs — or Witlings at the bar,</br>All met for mutual happiness and ease,</br>'Tis fitting each should have his turn to please;</br>This cast of parts unites colloquial charms,</br>Gives wit its point — and wisdom all its arms.

If press'd by Argument you can't reply,</br>—As where's the fountain that's not sometimes dry?—</br>Offer no WAGER to attest your cause,</br>This feeble prop of Conversation's laws;</br>Who argue thus can little else produce</br>In taste, or learning — ornament, or use,</br>Traffic's their forte in letters as in gains,</br>The pride of riches — and the lack of brains,</br>Unconscious of this truth — "A heavy purse</br>In a fool's pocket is a heavy curse."

LURED BY THE FOND DESIRE TO ENTERTAIN,</br>NO FAVOURITE TOPIC SHOULD ASPIRE TO REIGN,</br>Tho' it be yours to talk with varied grace,</br>And state minutely every nicer case,</br>The repetition blurs the gloss of art,</br>And sinks e'en talents to a second part;</br>Gives dulness front to smile with vacant leer,</br>And malice all its promptitude to sneer,</br>Combines the little wits, whose cunning lies</br>In meanly taking genius by surprize.

NOR YET THE PEDANT PLAY — but wiser know</br>What's fit for use — or academic show.</br>Who rich and prudent ever spreads his hoard,</br>In purse-proud conquest, o'er the public board?</br>Or who that feels what's honour's best defence,</br>Will arrogantly meditate offence?</br>The scholar thus — tho' deep in classic roots,</br>Displays his knowledge by progressive fruits,</br>By judgment — taste and language — these proclaim</br>The steadier — chaster attributes of fame.

Nor as the PEDANT'S SHADOW idly stand,</br>To pick up education second hand;</br>Or think the PARTIAL READING OF AN HOUR</br>Can ape the charms of literary power.</br>Such may amuse — nay sometimes work its ends,</br>And lull the sense of unsuspicious friends,</br>But be the Parrot's character his praise,</br>Who gives his mind to such delusive ways.</br>He that to sounder knowledge would aspire,</br>And gain those wreaths which zealous bosoms fire,</br>With pleasing toil, and emulative rage,</br>Should turn with constancy the letter'd page;</br>See how fair science beams upon the soul,</br>And trace from parts the union of the whole.</br>For who without foundations can commence</br>In arts — in arms — in building — or in sense?</br>For want of these, tho' meant for strength, or grace,</br>The proudest piles must topple to their base.</br>Yet there are times, when topics strike the view,</br>As not remember'd — or as wholly new,</br>Where partial reading comes with friendliest aid,</br>To fill the pause, which memory's lapse has made,</br>Or add some knowledge to the general store,</br>Which chance, nor education gave before;</br>These lighter studies aim at no pretence,</br>And gather laurels at a cheap expense.

Some, over hostile to the pedant line,</br>Will every wreath of scholarship resign,</br>And hence would chase QUOTATION from the train</br>Of social talk — as insolent and vain,</br>Unskill'd itself — yet confident to sing,</br>—Soaring the wren upon the eagle's wing—</br>But say, discreetly us'd — who can deny</br>The ready vantage of this old ally?</br>How now discourse by judgment 'twill support,</br>And now by elegance of thought pay court;</br>And now by wit, that brighter charm display,</br>Which bears the cause triumphantly away.</br>'Mongst strangers, lo!  the well-bred scholar finds,</br>'Tis the parole of literary minds,</br>The classic's sentiments, design and end</br>We greet — and hail him as our common friend—</br>"He's mine" — "He's your's" — exultingly we cry,</br>And feel alike — because he's our ally.

To gain this point — IMPLORE AT MEMORY'S SHRINE,</br>By every art which Memory may be thine;</br>By early study — by selection's skill,</br>By repetition — and determin'd will.</br>What, tho' at first she coyly feigns alarms,</br>With double energy pursue her charms,</br>Press — and press on, 'till like a yielding prude,</br>She gives up all, by time and truth subdued.</br>Nor think that MEMORY boasts her pow'rs aloud,</br>To catch the partial praises of the crowd,</br>A steadier friend — she loves retirement's shade,</br>And woos the thoughtful mind — by magic aid,</br>She brings with freshen'd grace before its view,</br>What poets sung — or what historians drew,</br>The hero's deeds — the sage's moral lay,</br>With all that valour — virtue could display.

O!  Powerful Goddess! — rich in means and end,</br>The Poet's parent, sometimes only friend,</br>How oft with thee, tho' fortune turn'd aside,</br>Nor deign'd a favourite glance from vulgar pride;</br>I've met with firmness all her wanton power.</br>—Thyself the heroine of my pensive hour!</br>How oft as list'ning to thy sapient tongue,</br>I shar'd the triumphs manly deeds have won,</br>Shrunk from ambition, and her pageant car,</br>And mourn'd the sad calamities of war.</br>Here saw, how Pride uprais'd her selfish head,</br>Whilst misery groan'd beneath its humble shed;</br>There saw Humanity her gifts bestow,</br>And heal the sorrows of domestic woe.</br>Revolving next o'er Plutarch's moral page,</br>View'd all the manly firmness of the sage,</br>How mild Philosophy attun'd his breast,</br>And Independence cheer'd his letter'd rest,</br>Spurning Ambition's anxious, giddy state,</br>And proving virtue only makes us great.</br>Thus all thy records spread before my eye,</br>—The world's great roll, where human actions lie—</br>The wondrous story search'd my every part,</br>And grav'd such useful lessons on my heart,</br>Display'd content in such a charming view,</br>To morals, — sense — and happiness so true;</br>I left the little lures of pomp behind,</br>And felt superior fortune in my mind;</br>"Be this my shield" — I cried — "midst cares and strife,</br>My guard 'gainst evil — and my guide through life."

Nor think, ye vain, whose bosoms idly glow,</br>And sigh for wants which often end in woe,</br>Fantastic wants!  which nature never nam'd,</br>Conceiv'd in pride — by novelties inflam'd,</br>Pageants of fashion, meteors of a day,</br>Intent on nothing — but their own display,</br>With whims unnumber'd as the fool's desires,</br>When emulation all his bosom fires,</br>Think not but joys await the humble line,</br>Where INDEPENDENCE rears its sacred shrine,</br>Where the still conscience gives that sweet repose,</br>Which casts our cares off nightly with our clothes,</br>Joys which surpass the meed of courtly praise,</br>Or useless riches — or the vulgar gaze.

Is it no joy — to scape that base-born sphere,</br>Where baser language wounds the modest ear,</br>Where Vice and Want their baneful influence spread</br>And Virtue scarcely lifts its drooping head?</br>Is it no joy to boast a liberal mind,</br>By books, by converse, and by taste refin'd,</br>From false Ambition free, from crimes of state,</br>And every wish that would be meanly great?</br>Is it no joy to prove this moral song,</br>"Man wants but little, nor that little long,"</br>Yet from that little, by a tim'd supply,</br>Arrest the widow's tear, the orphan's sigh,</br>Spread by example Charity around,</br>And feel its heaven-born comforts in rebound,</br>Thus rise by worth, respected without art,</br>And gain a patronage in every heart?

Is it no joy to hail the dawning day,</br>And view the wonders nature's works display?</br>The misty mountain's top — the cheering sun,</br>Just as his rising splendours are begun?</br>The feather'd choir who chaunt their Maker's praise</br>In the wild warblings of their matin lays,</br>Where every copse with artless music rings,</br>And every bliss is painted on their wings?</br>Th' enamelled meads that scent the passing gale,</br>And mix their fragrance with the flowery vale?</br>The mantling trees which climb each rising hill,</br>The stream that glides — or murmurs in the rill,</br>The spangled dew drops and the golden grain,</br>With all that decorate the rural plain,</br>With all that nature from her bounteous store</br>Bestows alike upon the rich and poor?

Say — can we view this ever glorious sight</br>Without the feel of exquisite delight?</br>This cheap resource to every thinking mind,</br>Where pleasure and religion are combined,</br>And not exclaim with gratitude divine,</br>"CREATION'S TENANT — all these scenes are mine!"?</br>Yes — these are joys which swell the good man's breast,</br>These are the hoards of which he feels possessed,</br>These point his duties to their noblest end</br>As HUSBAND — PARENT — CITZEN and FRIEND;</br>These tell the rich, debased by fortune's lure,</br>Tho' wealth oft wants — and grandeur's insecure,</br>That every poor man, is not therefore poor.
